key_facts: 2023 was the northern hemisphere's hottest summer in 2,000 years.
The 2023 summer was 2.07°C warmer than the pre-industrial average.
The 2023 summer was nearly 4°C warmer than the year 536.
Scientists used tree ring data to study historical temperatures.
The dataset included ancient and living trees from Europe and Asia.
Modern heat exceeds natural climate variability.
The 2023 heat was primarily driven by human-induced climate change.
El Niño contributed to the 2023 heat.
Historical temperatures may have been underestimated.
The study highlights the urgency of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
Without action, future warming could cause more severe impacts.
